fields.title: Ad Reinhardt — Toward Absolute Silence
fields.synopsis: Near-absolute blacks, radical reduction, path toward silence.
fields.content: Ad Reinhardt develops paintings made of nearly total black, stripped of any visual effects. He considers this extreme reduction the logical endpoint of a journey toward pure, silent, uncompromising painting.

fields.title: Helen Frankenthaler — Fluidity and Transparency
fields.synopsis: Fluid stains, diluted colors, stylistic transition.
fields.content: Helen Frankenthaler revolutionizes color with her soak-stain technique. Diluted pigments seep into raw canvas, producing an airy visual poetry that perfectly bridges Abstract Expressionism and Color Field Painting.

fields.title: Hans Hofmann — Push and Pull
fields.synopsis: Push and pull theory, chromatic intensity.
fields.content: Hans Hofmann combines expressive color with a foundational theory: push and pull. Through contrasts of color and plane, the pictorial surface breathes, stretches, and contracts, generating a unique spatial dynamism.

fields.title: Joan Mitchell — Lyrical Energy
fields.content: Joan Mitchell expresses raw emotional energy. Her broad brushstrokes and vibrant color fields embody the lyrical force of American abstraction, blending rage, light, and inner landscapes.

fields.title: Joan Mitchell — The Last Paintings
fields.synopsis: Vibrant yellow, late style, legacy of nature.
fields.content: In her final years, Mitchell's palette shifted toward incandescent yellows. These works, often huge diptychs, reflect her enduring dialogue with the French landscape and the passage of time.
